message.content:
<<<api>>>: String.getBytes
<<<code>>>: String password = "";
password = loginPasswordField.getText();
String md5hashdatabase = "3f197eedfeaf826ad2af0bac49ded752";
try {
    MessageDigest md = MessageDigest.getInstance("MD5");
    md.update(password.getBytes());
    byte[] passwordBytes = md.digest();
    String md5hashes = new BigInteger(1, passwordBytes).toString(16);
    String m = md5hashes;
    String myDriver = "org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver";
    String myUrl = "jdbc:mysql://experimentalx.com/exper482_social";
    Class.forName(myDriver);
    Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(myUrl, "admin", "test");
    String query = "SELECT password FROM social_users";
    Statement st = conn.createStatement();
    ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery(query);
    while (rs.next()) {
        String encryptedPassWord = rs.getString("password");
        System.out.format("%s\n", encryptedPassWord);
        if (m.equals(encryptedPassWord)) {
            System.out.println("Its exactly the same!");
        } else if (!m.equals(encryptedPassWord)) {
            System.out.println("Its not the same!");
        } else {
            System.out.println("For some reason, this is just not wanting to work!");
        }
    }
    st.close();
} catch (Exception e1) {
    System.err.println("Got an exception! ");
    System.err.println(e1.getMessage());
}
}
<<<explanation>>>: The code is using the getBytes() method of the String class to convert the password string into a byte array. This byte array is then used as input for the MessageDigest's update() method to calculate the MD5 hash. The resulting hash is converted to a string using the BigInteger class and compared with the encrypted password retrieved from the database. If they are equal, it prints "Its exactly the same!", otherwise it prints "Its not the same!".

prompt:
Please answer my code questions using the given API following this format: <<<api>>>: $API
<<<code>>>: $CODE
<<<explanation>>>: $EXPLANATION.
Question: How can I calculate the sum of an array in Java?
Please using this api: Arrays.stream.
Answer:<<<api>>>: Arrays.stream
<<<code>>>: int[] array = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5};
int sum = Arrays.stream(array).sum();
<<<explanation>>>: The sum() method of the IntStream class returns the sum of elements in this stream. This is a special case of a reduction. This is a terminal operation.
Question: Checking two passwords to see if they are equal: :I have a code in JAVA which connects to a database and gets the password for every user in the database.Here is the code:private void loginButtonActionPerformed(ActionEvent e) {    String password = "";        password=loginPasswordField.getText();        String md5hashdatabase = "3f197eedfeaf826ad2af0bac49ded752";                    try        {            MessageDigest md = MessageDigest.getInstance("MD5");            md.update(password.getBytes());            System.out.println(new BigInteger(1, md.digest()).toString(16));            String md5hashes = new BigInteger(1, md.digest()).toString(16);            String m = md5hashes;            String myDriver = "org.gjt.mm.mysql.Driver";            String myUrl = "jdbc:mysql://experimentalx.com/exper482_social";            Class.forName(myDriver);            Connection conn = DriverManager.getConnection(myUrl, "admin", "test");            String query = "SELECT password FROM social_users";            Statement st = conn.createStatement();            ResultSet rs = st.executeQuery(query);            while (rs.next())            {                String encryptedPassWord = rs.getString("password");                System.out.format("%s\n", encryptedPassWord);                if(m.equals(encryptedPassWord))                 {                    System.out.println("Its exactly the same!");                }                else if(!m.equals(encryptedPassWord))                 {                    System.out.println("Its not the same!");                }                else                {                    System.out.println("For some reason, this is just not wanting to work!");                }                     }            st.close();        }        catch (Exception e1)        {            System.err.println("Got an exception! ");            System.err.println(e1.getMessage());        }       }It gets the passwords, and then checks if the string md5hash is the same as one of the md5 hashes recieved from the database(encryptedPassWord).  When it does this, it just says that all of them are not the same, even though the first hash from the database is the same as the string m(md5hashes).Have i missed out something?  If so can you please guide me in the right path.  Thank you.
Please using this api: String.getBytes.
